description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: On March 16 2020, the Finnish government announces that primary schools will be shutdown and contact teaching will be suspended. Exceptions to this are pre-primary education and contact teaching for grades 1-3 will continue for children of parents working in sectors critical to the functioning of society. A further exception will be for pupils who require contact teaching based on special needs. Instead of contact teaching, education will be provided, to the widest extent possible in alternative ways, including distance learning, various digital learning environments, and, where necessary, self-learning.

description:
"On 29 April, the Finnish government announces new guidelines and instructions for childhood education and childcare facilities. The guidelines include:
- avoidance of unnecessary physical contact
- arranging teaching premises more spacious than usual
- school break times and school meals must be held with the student's own class or group
- no large gatherings, such as spring festivals
- personnel must work with the same group of children and hygiene guidelines must be strictly respected

The school year is set to end on 30 May.

description: On May 4 2020, the Finnish government says that upper secondary, vocational, higher education institutions and liberal education will be controlled through measures in line with Communicable Disease act and that contact teaching may resume during the summer semester in a controlled and gradual manner. The government recommends that universities, universities of applied sciences, upper secondary schools, vocational schools, liberal adult education and basic adult education institutes continue distance teaching until the end of the semester. No student, teacher, or staff may visit school premises if symptoms are occur. If a student is living in a dormitory attached to an educational institution becomes ill, the educational institution must contact the staff member in charge of infectious diseases and assess the situation and take the required measures.

description: On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education announces new measures for schools and educational institutions. In lower secondary schools and in optional subjects, teaching groups may change if the teaching cannot be organised any other way. Safe distances of 1 to 2 meters should be maintained in general upper secondary schools, vocational education and training institutes, higher education institutions and liberal adult education. Providers of general upper secondary education and vocational education and training and higher education may flexibly decide on safe and appropriate teaching methods and arrangements. If teaching is arranged for a large number of people, it is advisable to use remote connections.

description: On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education amends the Act on Vocational Education and Training temporarily. In higher education institutions, a student may register as a non-attending student during the first academic year if he or she is prevented from starting his or her studies due to an official regulation related to the epidemic or for another epidemic-related serious reason. If studies are delayed due to exceptional teaching arrangements introduced by a higher education institution because of the coronavirus epidemic, this will be taken into account when deciding on the extension of the right to study. The amendments made to the Act on Vocational Education and Training, the Universities Act and the Universities of Applied Sciences Act will remain in force until 31 July 2021.

description: On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education announces new measures for early childhood education and care. Early childhood education and care should be organised so that groups are not mixed or combined. Staff members in early childhood education and care should also work with the same group of children. Children starting school or early childhood education and their parents will be given an opportunity to familiarise themselves with activities in advance, provided that good hygiene is ensured and there are not too many people in the same space at the same time. Children may bring along an important toy and take it home at the end of the day.

description: On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education announces new measures for schools and educational institutions. In primary schools, the different teaching groups should be kept separate throughout the school day. Activities should be staggered with the aim that that there are few people in the same space as possible. Staff members should also avoid assembling, which means, for example, that teachers should hold their meetings remotely. If contact teaching cannot be organised safely - as will be assessed in cooperation with regional authorities, then contact teaching and distance learning can be alternated, by placing groups in distance learning in alternate weeks. This does not apply to students in years 1-3 who have special needs support or students in extended compulsory or preparatory education. Students have the right to school meals, support for learning and school attendance, study guidance, and students benefits during exceptional arrangements.

description:
On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education amends the Act on Vocational Education and Training temporarily. If, for reasons attributable to the coronavirus epidemic, a demonstration of the professional skills and competence required to pass a qualification module cannot be conducted in authentic work situations and processes, a student may demonstrate his or her professional skills and competence by performing other practical tasks that are as similar to authentic work situations and processes as possible. In addition, the demonstration of skills and competence can be supplemented with other types of competence assessment more flexibly than at present.
 The amendments made to the Act on Vocational Education and Training, the Universities Act and the Universities of Applied Sciences Act will remain in force until 31 July 2021.

description: On 29 June 2021, the Finnish government announces temporary amendments to the Basic Education Act and the Act on the European School of Helsinki beginning on 1 August 2021 to 31 July 2022. The amendments are aimed at ensuring the right of students to have a school meal, support for learning, and school attendance. Autumn term will be organized as contact teaching but education providers can decide to switch to distance learning if needed and switch to an alternating schedule of one week of contact learning and one week of distance learning. These assessments must be carried out in cooperation with regional authorities.

description: On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education amends the Act on Vocational Education and Training temporarily. In higher education institutions, a student may register as a non-attending student during the first academic year if he or she is prevented from starting his or her studies due to an official regulation related to the epidemic or for another epidemic-related serious reason. If studies are delayed due to exceptional teaching arrangements introduced by a higher education institution because of the coronavirus epidemic, this will be taken into account when deciding on the extension of the right to study. The amendments made to the Act on Vocational Education and Training, the Universities Act and the Universities of Applied Sciences Act will remain in force until 31 July 2021. UPDATE: On 29 June 2021, the Finnish government extends the policy to 1 July 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 16 April 2021, the Government amended the decree on voluntary COVID-19 vaccinations. The amended decree will specify Finland’s current order of priority for COVID-19 vaccination. The decree will enter into force on 19 April 2021. Once vaccines have been given to the three main priority groups — people at risk, older people and healthcare and social welfare workers caring for COVID-19 patients — the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group. Vaccines will be administered in descending order as follows: 60–69-year-olds, 50–59-year-olds, 40–49-year-olds, 30–39-year-olds and 16–29-year-olds.

description:
On March 16 2020, Finland announces that only necessary travel for work and to essential commuter traffic across borders will be permitted across with Sweden. Essential commuter traffic is traffic related to the duties of healthcare and rescue service personnel, health researchers and elderly care professionals
Transport personnel and other transport staff to the extent necessary
Diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
Necessary (return) transit and returns
Passengers travelling for imperative family reasons
Persons in need of international protection or who travel for other humanitarian reasons
Other necessary and justified traffic. This includes, for example, maintenance work that requires a maintenance team or a person arriving from another country and that cannot be postponed.  Freight traffic will continue as usual.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 16 March 2020, Finland announces that it will begin restricting its cross-border traffic by closing border crossing points and establishing border control measures. Passenger transport to Finland will be suspended as soon as possible, with exception of the return of Finnish citizens, EU citizens, and Schengen citizens and persons residing in Finland. description: Finland places restrictions on its external border starting Thursday, March 19. All individuals arriving from abroad are asked to fill in a form to assess their exposure before arriving at border security. Their forms will then be assessed and passengers will then be directed to either go home or be to directed to a health checkpoint. Those experiencing symptoms will be directed to sampling and brought to a hotel accommodation to wait for results. If the result is positive, they will be transferred to healthcare.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
"On 18 March 2020, the Finnish government announces border restrictions on its border control measures on its borders. Entry into FInland is possible by nationals of other Schengen countries and their family members, third-country nationals residing in another Schengen country with a residence permit for necessary traffic, which is defined as: traffic related to the duties of healthcare and rescue service personnel, health researchers and elderly care professionals
Transport personnel and other transport staff to the extent necessary
Diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
Necessary (return) transit and returns
Passengers travelling for imperative family reasons
Persons in need of international protection or who travel for other humanitarian reasons
Other necessary and justified traffic. This includes, for example, maintenance work that requires a maintenance team or a person arriving from another country and that cannot be postponed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 10 March, 2020, Finland decides to suspend decisions on visa applications in Finland's missions until further notice. description: The Finnish government bans workers who commute from Estonia to Finland on 20 March. Workers who permanently reside in Estonia but commute for Finland for work must choose where they reside. 'Hopefully, people working permanently in Finland will stay in Finland', the Finnish Minister of Interior said. Finland will not obstruct Estonians from leaving Finland, but those who do, will not be able to re-enter the country from March 22.

description:
On April 6, Finland's Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry and Ministry for Economic Affairs and Employment decide, based on a joint working group formed in March, that the 'use of foreign seasonal labour is particularly important in tasks requiring expertise gained from previous years’. The essential tasks requiring foreign labour are:
1) agriculture, horticulture and fisheries, 2) the food sector, 3) energy supply, 4) maritime and manufacturing industries, 5) construction, 6) transport and communications, 7) chemical industry, 8) pharmaceutical and health technology industries and 9) the forest sector. 

The government decides on measures for a 'first-stage reception of 1,500 employees in terms of the allocation of labour and the transport and quarantine of employees'.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 7 April, Finland decides to reduce movement 'in the common travel-to-work area along the borders Norway' to strictly 'necessary travel'. Employees must 'carry a certificate from their employer stating that their work is essential'. Finland calls on employers to 'explore ways of reducing the cross-border movement of workers, for example by providing employees with accomodation near where they work'.

description: On March 16 2020, Finland announces that Finnish citizens should not travel abroad. Finnish tourists are advised to return to Finland immediately. UPDATE: Following negotiations on the 3-4 May 2020, the Finnish government decides to extends recommendations for Finnish citizens to avoid recreational travel abroad.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7 2020, the Finnish government announces restrictions on border traffic and quarantine rules will be tightened until 13 May 2020 for Sweden. Essential travel and other necessary traffic will be allowed. Employees crossing the border into Finland from Sweden must have a certificate from their employer stating that the work is essential. UPDATE: On May 4 2020, the Finnish government decides to lift cross-border traffic restrictions across the Schengen borders and allows 'employment or commission-related commuting and other essential traffic'. The policy will take into effect on 14 May 2020. UPDATE: The government lifts traffic restrictions across the Schengen borders.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 7 April 2020, Finland decides to reduce movement 'in the common travel-to-work area along the borders Norway' to strictly 'necessary travel'. Employees must 'carry a certificate from their employer stating that their work is essential'. Finland calls on employers to 'explore ways of reducing the cross-border movement of workers, for example by providing employees with accommodation near where they work'.
 UPDATE: On May 4, the Finnish government decides to lift cross-border traffic restrictions across the Schengen borders and allows 'employment or commission-related commuting and other essential traffic'. The policy will take into effect on 14 May.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 7 2020, the Finnish government announces that the border between Finland and Estonia will be closed aside from essential work, which is defined as personnel working in healthcare, elderly care, and rescue services. Other necessary work includes work that is necessary for the functioning of society or the security of supply. UPDATE: On May 5 2020, the Finnish government announces the gradual dismantling of restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 16 March 2020, Finland announces that it will begin restricting its cross-border traffic by closing border crossing points and establishing border control measures. Passenger transport to Finland will be suspended as soon as possible, with exception of the return of Finnish citizens and persons residing in Finland. Finnish citizens and persons residing in Finland must not travel abroad.  Freight traffic will continue as usual. UPDATE: Restrictions placed on Finland's borders are extended until 14 June 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On 18 March 2020, the Finnish government announces border restrictions on its border control measures on its borders. Entry into FInland is possible by nationals of other Schengen countries and their family members, third-country nationals residing in another Schengen country with a residence permit for necessary traffic, which is defined as: traffic related to the duties of healthcare and rescue service personnel, health researchers and elderly care professionals
Transport personnel and other transport staff to the extent necessary
Diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
Necessary (return) transit and returns
Passengers travelling for imperative family reasons
Persons in need of international protection or who travel for other humanitarian reasons
Other necessary and justified traffic. This includes, for example, maintenance work that requires a maintenance team or a person arriving from another country and that cannot be postponed. UPDATE: On May 7 2020, the Finnish government announces that it will extend its restrictions on border traffic to 14 June 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable),Other population not specifed above
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 7 May 2020, the Finnish government announces that while restrictions between Finland and Sweden will be lifted, that border control will continue at land borders, ports, and airports. Only a number of borders are allowed to be used for passenger traffic, including the Karesuvanto, Kolari, Munonio, Pello, Tornio, and Ylitornia road border. Crossing the border between Sweden and Finland is permitted for purposes of fishing as long as there is no landfall on Finnish territory.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 7 2020, the Finnish government announces that it will restrict goods and freight transport to certain ports. The air traffic ports of Enontekiö, Helsinki Malm, Ivalo, Joensuu, Jyväskylä, Kajaani, Kemi-Tornio, Kittilä, Kokkola-Pietarsaari, Kuopio, Kuusamo, Lappeenranta, Mikkeli, Oulu, Pori, Rovaniemi, Savonlinna, Seinäjoki and Tampere-Pirkkala airports will only allow freight transport. The Helsinki-Vantaa, Mariehamn and Turku airports will also allow goods traffic. The water ports of Eckerö, Eurajoki, Färjsundet, Förby, Hamina, Hanko, Haukiputa, Inkoo, Kalajoki, Kaskinen, Kemi, Kemiö, Kirkkonummi, Kokkola, Kotka, Kristiinankaupunki, Lappeenranta, Loviisa, Maarianhamina, Merikarvia, Naantali, Nuijamaa, Oulu, Parainen, Pernaja, Pietarsaari, Pohja, Pori, Porvo, Raahe, Rauma, Salo, Sipo, Taalintehdas, Tammisaarei, Tornio and Uusikaupunki are allowed for freight traffic only. In terms of the road transport, the border points between Finland and Sweden at Karesuvanto, Kolari, Muonio, Pello, Tornio and Ylitornio are allowed for goods traffic.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 7 May 2020, the Finnish government reinstates border closures, only allowing return traffic to Finland from Estonia, travel for work, and other essential traffic. Return traffic to Finland is defined as Finnish citizens and their family members
b) citizens of the EU and Schengen States living in Finland and their family members
c) third-country nationals residing in Finland with a residence permit. Travel for work and other essential traffic is defined as a) employment or commission-related commuting
b) diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and personnel of aid organisations in their duties
c) persons studying in Finland
d) persons arriving in Finland with a residence permit (including EU/Schengen citizens who have registered their right of residence and seasonal workers from a third country according to a separate quota)
e) persons travelling for imperative family reasons (e.g. travelling to meet with an immediate family member or for their funeral, wedding or illness)
f) persons in need of international protection or travelling otherwise for humanitarian reasons
g) other essential and justified traffic (e.g. pressing personal reasons, representatives of foreign media, Sámi livelihoods and culture).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 20 May, the Finnish Immigration Service decides to lower the cost of visa processing fees from EUR 520 to EUR 150 for adults and from EUR 270 to EUR 100 for minors. This will be specifically for cases where the permit is applied for because of the travel restrictions imposed because of the COVID19 pandemic. It will enter into force on 22 May 2020 and will end on 31 October 2020. 
Possible applicants include: people whose visa-free stay, visa, or residence permit has expired.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

The final decision to be made by the Border Guard.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
"On April 6, Finland's Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry and Ministry for Economic Affairs and Employment decide, based on a joint working group formed in March, that the 'use of foreign seasonal labour is particularly important in tasks requiring expertise gained from previous years’. The essential tasks requiring foreign labour are:
1) agriculture, horticulture and fisheries, 2) the food sector, 3) energy supply, 4) maritime and manufacturing industries, 5) construction, 6) transport and communications, 7) chemical industry, 8) pharmaceutical and health technology industries and 9) the forest sector. 

The government decides on measures for a 'first-stage reception of 1,500 employees in terms of the allocation of labour and the transport and quarantine of employees'." UPDATE: The original policy allowed for 1,500 seasonal workers and it was updated to 4,500 on 29 May 2020.
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 7 2020, the Finnish government announces that while restrictions restrictions between Finland and Norway will be lifted, that border control will continue at land borders, ports, and airports. Only a number of borders are allowed to be used for passenger traffic, including the Karigasniemi, Kilpisjärvi, Kivilompolo, Nuorgam, Näätämö and Utsjoki ports. The crossing of boundaries between Finland and Norway is permitted for fishing purposes as long as it does not involve making landfall. UPDATE: On 12 June 2020, Finland announces the loosening of restrictions and will allow the entry of persons under certain circumstances. Finland also opens airports and harbors for all pleasure crafts.

description:
On June 12, the Finnish government decides to make changes to its border control policies. Border controls will be lifted on June 15 from the land border between Finland and Norway, on air services and scheduled ferry services between Finland and Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, and recreational boat travel (i.e. private boats). 
Border controls will continue between Finland and the Schengen countries, besides those mentioned above, and Finnish citizens are advised not to travel to any other country besides those above.

description: On June 12, the Finnish government announces that 14 day quarantine measures are voluntary for those entering Finland from countries that are still subject to border controls, such as Sweden and Russia. UPDATE: On June 17 2020, the Finnish government no longer requires health screening.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 7 May 2020, the Finnish government announces that while restrictions between Finland and Sweden will be lifted, that border control will continue at land borders, ports, and airports. Only a number of borders are allowed to be used for passenger traffic, including the Karesuvanto, Kolari, Munonio, Pello, Tornio, and Ylitornia road border. Crossing the border between Sweden and Finland is permitted for purposes of fishing as long as there is no landfall on Finnish territory. UPDATE: On 12 June 2020, the Finnish government announces more loosening of restrictions between Finland and Sweden.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 16 March 2020, Finland announces that it will begin restricting its cross-border traffic by closing border crossing points and establishing border control measures. Passenger transport to Finland will be suspended as soon as possible, with exception of the return of Finnish citizens and persons residing in Finland. Finnish citizens and persons residing in Finland must not travel abroad.  Freight traffic will continue as usual. UPDATE: On 6 June 2020, the Finnish government announces a decision to extend the restrictions on its border until 14 July 2020. The original policy was set to end on 14 June 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 7 2020, the Finnish government announces that it will loosen restrictions for entry into Finland from Schengen countries, no longer requiring a justification for the commute across the border but that you can may only enter Finland for imperative family reasons other essential or justified traffic Travelling into Finland for reasons of recreational travel is prohibited and the final decision on whether the conditions for entry are met are to be made by the Border Guard except Denmark, Iceland, Lithuania, Sweden, Norway, and Estonia. UPDATE: On 12 June 2020, the Finnish government announces that restrictions will continue for a number of Schengen countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 18 March 2020, the Finnish government announces border restrictions on its border control measures on its borders. Entry into FInland is possible by nationals of other Schengen countries and their family members, third-country nationals residing in another Schengen country with a residence permit for necessary traffic, which is defined as: traffic related to the duties of healthcare and rescue service personnel, health researchers and elderly care professionals
Transport personnel and other transport staff to the extent necessary
Diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
Necessary (return) transit and returns
Passengers travelling for imperative family reasons
Persons in need of international protection or who travel for other humanitarian reasons
Other necessary and justified traffic. This includes, for example, maintenance work that requires a maintenance team or a person arriving from another country and that cannot be postponed. UPDATE: On 6 June 2020, the Finnish government announces that it will extend restrictions on border traffic to 14 July 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable),Other population not specifed above
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 10 March, 2020, Finland decides to suspend decisions on visa applications in Finland's missions until further notice. 'Passports related to visa applications under consideration will be returned' and will not be processed, with the exception of those from Russia. Individuals who are applying for a visa who have Finnish citizen family member may also fall under this exemption. UPDATE: Finland suspended visa and residence permit applications back in March and decided to gradually resume the applications on 16 June.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On 1 June 2020, the Finnish Border Guard announces that it will begin to do border checks for those exiting Finland. Entry checks will continue. The reason for the checks, the Border Guard says, is due to a stark increase of recreational boat traffic, which has significantly increased the maritime rescue tasks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On June 12, the Finnish government decides to make changes to its border control policies. Border controls will be lifted on June 15 from the land border between Finland and Norway, on air services and scheduled ferry services between Finland and Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, and recreational boat travel (i.e. private boats). 
Border controls will continue between Finland and the Schengen countries, besides those mentioned above, and Finnish citizens are advised not to travel to any other country besides those above. On July 8, the Finnish government ends this policy. UPDATE: On July 10, the geographic target of the policy has changed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On 10 July the Finnish government decided that from 13 July, 2020 external border traffic between Finland and EU countries that do not belong to the Schengen area, as well as the United Kingdom, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican will be allowed if number of cases in countries on the list do not exceed 8 cases of infection per 100,000 people. Thus, travel is unrestricted between Finland and Cyprus, Ireland, Andorra, San Marino and the Vatican. For Finland and Bulgaria, Croatia, Romania, the United Kingdom and Monaco restrictions stay the same. Travel is allowed between Finland and Algeria, Australia, South Korea, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay and China.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 13 July, 2020, berry pickers are allowed to enter Finland by the invitation of companies via both internal and external border traffic. description:
On 18 March 2020, the Finnish government announces border restrictions on its border control measures on its borders. Entry into FInland is possible by nationals of other Schengen countries and their family members, third-country nationals residing in another Schengen country with a residence permit for necessary traffic, which is defined as: traffic related to the duties of healthcare and rescue service personnel, health researchers and elderly care professionals
Transport personnel and other transport staff to the extent necessary
Diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
Necessary (return) transit and returns
Passengers travelling for imperative family reasons
Persons in need of international protection or who travel for other humanitarian reasons
Other necessary and justified traffic. This includes, for example, maintenance work that requires a maintenance team or a person arriving from another country and that cannot be postponed. UPDATE: On 23 June 2020, the Finnish government announces that it will lift restrictions from Croatia, Cyprus, and Ireland.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable),Other population not specifed above
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 16 March 2020, Finland announces that it will begin restricting its cross-border traffic by closing border crossing points and establishing border control measures. Passenger transport to Finland will be suspended as soon as possible, with exception of the return of Finnish citizens, EU citizens, and Schengen citizens and persons residing in Finland. Finnish citizens and persons residing in Finland must not travel abroad.  Freight traffic will continue as usual. UPDATE: On 13 July 2020, the Finnish government announces changes to its border restrictions with a number of countries, lifting a number of restrictions to: Andorra, San Marino, the Vatican, Algeria, Australia, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, and China.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On 19 August 2020, the Finnish government reinstates border restrictions against Germany. Those who are allowed to enter include Return to Finland

a) Finnish nationals and their family members
b) nationals of EU and Schengen countries residing in Finland and their family members
c) third-country nationals residing in Finland with a residence permit
- Return traffic to other EU and Schengen countries or via them

a) nationals of other EU and Schengen countries and their family members
b) third-country nationals residing another EU or Schengen country with a residence permit
- Work trip and other essential traffic

a) work trip based on employment or assignment
b) diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
c) persons studying in Finland
d) persons with a Finnish residence permit and EU/Schengen citizens who have registered their right of residence
e) persons travelling for family matters (e.g. meeting a relative, relationship, funerals, weddings, illness)
f) persons in need of international protection or who are travelling for other humanitarian reasons
g) other necessary and justified reason (e.g. necessary personal reasons, representatives of foreign media, transit at the airport, property, residence or secondary residence in Finland, property arrangements in Finland, pursuit of the Sámi livelihood and culture).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 11 September, the Finnish governments adopts new decisions on the regulation of external borders and will now categorise countries and regions with more than 25 cases per 100,000 inhabitations within 14 days as areas with a high infection rate.  The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare will assess the categories of these incidences on a weekly basis. Aside from certain exceptions, a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken less than 72 hours prior to arrival would be required for those arriving from areas with a high infection rate.

description: On 11 September,2020, the Finnish Government adopted a decision on restrictions on border traffic, which will enter into force on 19 September and continue until 18 October. Restrictions on entry will be lifted for traffic between Finland and Cyprus, Germany, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Poland and Sweden, as well as for residents of Australia, Canada and Japan who are travelling from their home country to Finland. Lifting of restrictions on traffic between Finland and those EU and Schengen countries where the incidence of new cases has not exceeded 25 new cases per 100,000 persons in the previous 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"On 19 August, the Finnish government reinstates border restrictions against Germany. Those who are allowed to enter include Return to Finland

a) Finnish nationals and their family members
b) nationals of EU and Schengen countries residing in Finland and their family members
c) third-country nationals residing in Finland with a residence permit
- Return traffic to other EU and Schengen countries or via them

a) nationals of other EU and Schengen countries and their family members
b) third-country nationals residing another EU or Schengen country with a residence permit
- Work trip and other essential traffic

a) work trip based on employment or assignment
b) diplomats, staff of international organisations, military personnel and humanitarian aid workers in the exercise of their duties
c) persons studying in Finland
d) persons with a Finnish residence permit and EU/Schengen citizens who have registered their right of residence
e) persons travelling for family matters (e.g. meeting a relative, relationship, funerals, weddings, illness)
f) persons in need of international protection or who are travelling for other humanitarian reasons
g) other necessary and justified reason (e.g. necessary personal reasons, representatives of foreign media, transit at the airport, property, residence or secondary residence in Finland, property arrangements in Finland, pursuit of the Sámi livelihood and culture)." UPDATE: On 11 September 2020, the Finnish government announces that restrictions for entry with Germany will be lifted.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Finnish government announced that restrictions will be eased for travelers from 21 countries from Monday, September 21. Arrivals from Cyprus, Estonia, Germany, Iceland, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Norway, Slovakia, Sweden, and the Vatican City, as well as residents of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay, can enter the country without restrictions. description: Starting from October 1, 2020, residents of Finland returning from countries with higher incidence rates could, at their discretion, shorten the 14-day period of self-isolation by taking a test at the airport or port as soon as they arrive in Finland, followed by a second test in their home municipality after 72 hours at the earliest from taking the first test.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From October 1, 2020, non-residents arriving to Finland are recommended to take the first test up to 72 hours (3 days) before arrival. The second test should be taken no earlier than 72 hours (3 days) after entry into the country. Until receiving the result of the second test, persons entering the country should remain in self-isolation at their place of residence. The self-isolation period will end if the test result is negative. If the test result is positive, the doctor will place the person in quarantine until they have recovered.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description: As of January 22 2021, the Finnish government decided that belonging to a border community at Finland's land border with Sweden or Norway is no longer a valid reason for entry. In practice, this applies only to non-Finnish citizens. Finnish citizens and those living in Finland can continue to cross the border under the Constitution. Furthermore, residents of border communities no longer have the right to cross the border other than through border crossing points. This also applies to Finnish citizens, who will have to cross the border through the border crossing points set out in the decision. This would provide health authorities with the widest possible scope for targeting the necessary health measures at those crossing the border. The restrictions do not apply to the constitutional right of the Saami to practise their livelihoods and culture.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description: As of January 22 2021, according to the Constitution of Finland, Finnish citizens and residents of Finland always have the right to return to Finland, and everyone has the right to leave Finland, provided that there is no legal impediment to this. However, the Government still recommends avoiding unnecessary travel to other countries, except for countries for which the restrictions on entry have been lifted. Travellers must be aware of the current entry and quarantine regulations of their country of destination.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of 27 January, Finland will restrict entry from all Schengen countries. Only essential travel for work, that is important for the functioning of society or for security of supply, that must be performed by a person or persons arriving from another country and that must be carried without a delay, will be permitted. The Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment maintains a list of the work that is considered important for the functioning of society or for security of supply. However, employers must use a separate form to justify why the job of a worker seeking entry into Finland is essential and why the work must be performed without delay. Entry for foreign nationals from Schengen countries and from other third countries its permitted only for imperative family reasons, e.g. the birth of one's own child. Entry is still permitted for healthcare and rescue service personnel, and a number of other professions and duties.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of February 16, 2021, upon arrival to Finland, all travelers from the UK, Ireland, or South Africa must enter mandatory self-isolation for 14 days due to variants of COVID-19 active in those countries. These travelers are also required to provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test result taken within the previous 72 hours upon arrival. Authorities also recommend all individuals arriving from other restricted countries self-isolate for 10 days. All self-isolation requirements can be shortened by taking two voluntary COVID-19 tests. Travelers should take the first test up to 72 hours before arrival, or at the airport upon arrival for Finnish citizens and residents, and the second test no earlier than 72 hours after entering the country. Such individuals should remain in self-isolation until the result is known. If the test result is negative, the self-isolation period ends; if the test result is positive, the person will be placed in quarantine until they have recovered.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 18, 2021, the Finnish Government decided to extend the current restrictions on entry into the country until March 18, 2021. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to spread, and there are not yet adequate measures available to replace internal border controls. For this reason, and to curb the spread of COVID-19 variants, both internal and external border controls will continue until 18 March. No substantive changes will be made to the decisions taken on February 11, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of March 19, 2021, the opening hours of certain border crossing points at the western border in Lapland and the eastern border will be restricted. The aim of these changes is to concentrate cross-border traffic mainly to daytime and evening hours. This will ensure that the health authorities have sufficient resources at the border. The objective is to guide all people crossing the Finnish border to a COVID-19 test, unless they can present proof of a sufficiently recent negative COVID-19 test or proof of recovery from COVID-19. The limited opening hours do not apply to goods transport or to necessary passenger traffic with a justified reason to cross the border outside the opening hours. The restriction will continue till 17 April 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From June 21, 2021, Finnish authorities eased the nation's COVID-19 related international entry restrictions. All travelers from the EU and Schengen countries who can provide evidence of being fully vaccinated as well as those who have recovered from the disease no longer than six months prior to entry will be allowed to enter without restrictions.

description: From June 21, Authorities eased the nation's COVID-19-related international entry restrictions. All travelers from the EU and Schengen countries who can provide evidence of being fully vaccinated as well as those who have recovered from the disease no longer than six months prior to entry will be allowed to enter without restrictions. In addition, all those traveling from the EU and Schengen countries for business purposes will be allowed to enter. Officials are also lifting entry restrictions for all travelers arriving from San Marino, Monaco, Romania, Poland, and Hungary. Nationals and residents of Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, Israel, Rwanda, Malta, and Iceland may also enter Finland without restrictions. The entry measures are in effect through July 11. Other countries are still prohibited with exceptions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As of July 26, 2021, the Finnish government claimed no travel restrictions to both vaccinated and unvaccinated travelers to Finland from all EU and Schengen Area countries (Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, The Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, The Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland), and from Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City State. Unvaccinated travelers may be required to submit to a COVID-19 test and self-isolate until they receive a negative result unless they can prove they have recovered from the disease within six months prior to entry. Travelers who have received the first dose of a two-dose vaccine at least 14 days prior to entering Finland or who can present a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival must also take a COVID-19 test 3-5 days after arrival and self-isolate until receiving a negative test result.

description: On 8 April 2020, the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) announced a study inviting "Finnish citizens, based on random sampling, to participate in a study assessing the spread of the new coronavirus in the population...The main purpose of the current study is to gather up-to-date data on how large a proportion of the population has formed antibodies that would indicate previous contact with the virus (referred to as the ‘seroprevalence’). In addition, the study will measure the quantity of antibodies and monitor how long the antibodies remain in the body." The first study was supposed to be published on 30 April 2020. The study would continue until the end of the year.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 3 April 2020, "the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health urges the municipalities and social welfare units to pay special attention to appropriate action and prevention of the coronavirus in housing service units providing 24-hour care. To prevent the spread of the coronavirus, residents must not be moved from a place of care or housing unit to another one during the epidemic, unless this is absolutely necessary to ensure their care...Residents showing symptoms should, whenever possible, be placed in single rooms and in the same department. Residents showing symptoms and asymptomatic residents must not be treated in the same room."

description: On 18 March 2020, The Finnish government enforces exceptions made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act, in both the private and public sector, to oblige trained professionals in healthcare and social welfare to perform work as necessary. If necessary, the employer is allowed to suspend of postpone the employee's leave and can also deviate from the obligation to obtain consent for the employee to work overtime. The employer can also extend the notice period to four months, if a shortage of labour, due to the coronavirus, is imminent.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 31 March 2020, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment launched a project aimed primarily at launching domestic production of protective materials needed in the healthcare sector. Three companies – Filterpak Oy, Lifa Air Oy and Teho Filter Oy – launched the production of surgical masks and face coverings in addition to the production of medical gowns and aprons. Another three Finnish companies, Screentec Oy, SJT-Investment Group Oy and Eagle Filters Oy, are also about to launch the production of respiratory protective equipment.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On April 6, the Finnish government clarified a measure that gave municipalities the right to 'deviate from time limits for non-urgent care and social welfare services'. The decree clarified that the deviation of non-urgent care 'must not pute the health of patients at risk'. Furthermore, urgent social welfare cases must be 'assessed immediately' and that 'the right to essential care and livelihood and adequate social services must not be compromised'. UPDATE: On April 6, the government clarified the policy it enacted under the Emergency Powers Act.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 9 March 2020, The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health extended the validity of section 87 of the Emergency Powers Act to require "pharmacies to temporarily restrict the sale of certain salbutamol products more than in the above-mentioned decision on the dispensing of medicinal products in general. The aim of the restriction on sales is to ensure the sufficiency and equal accessibility of these medicines to all patients throughout Finland." These requirements will be in force until 13 May 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18 March 2020, The Finnish government enforces exceptions made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act, in both the private and public sector, to oblige trained professionals in healthcare and social welfare to perform work as necessary. UPDATE: On 6 April 2020, the Finnish government extends its exceptions to the provision of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act until 13 May 2020, to oblige private and public sectors healthcare workers to perform work as necessary.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 17 March 2020, the Government of Finland invokes paragraph 87 of its Emergency Powers Act, immediately granting the Government authority to limit the sale of medicines, supplies and services used in health care throughout the country. The authority was initially granted up to and including 13 April 2020. UPDATE: On 9 April 2020, The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health has decided to extend the validity of a decision made under section 87 of the Emergency Powers Act. The decisions will be in force until 13 May 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 20 April 2020, The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health has issued guidance on what needs to be done in the healthcare and social welfare sector to increase operational capability before the work obligation of the Emergency Powers Act can be applied. The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health recommends that the service organisers take proactive measures to strengthen and maintain the activities of the healthcare and social welfare sector. Primary measures include: reorganising work activities, acquiring services from private service providers and third-sector operators, and recruiting backup employees.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 8 May 2020, The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health points out that municipalities must also provide healthcare and social welfare services during the COVID-19 epidemic. Municipalities must actively provide information on their services to avoid any critical delays in people seeking care or accessing services. To ensure access to basic public services under these emergency conditions, it is necessary to adopt new practices and promote wider use of remote services.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 29 May, the Finnish government announces the reopening of domestic tourism and set in a number of specific guidelines to be followed. This includes:
- sick persons should avoid all travel
- symptoms must be reported immediately to healthcare services of the municipality or city where you are staying
- if a domestic tourist becomes infected with the coronavirus,the physician responsible for diseases in the municipality or hospital district is responsible for tracing the infection

description: On 30 March, the Finnish government expands the COVID-19 Coordination Group, which was set up in February to cover the Permanent Secretaries of all ministries. The Coordination Group will also include the Director of Government Security Ahti Kurvinen, Director of Government Communications Paivi Anttikoski, Head of Unit Heikki Hovi and the Director of the National Institute for Health and Welfare Mika Salminen. The group is chaired by Mikko Koskinen. A Situation Center is also opened, which is operated under the Prime Minister's office, and is focused on monitoring corona and its effects. It is tasked with maintaining 'the situational picture and communicating it to the President of the Republic, the Government and other authorities'. An Operations Center is also established under the Prime Minister's Office 'to maintain an overall picture of the progress made in implementing the Government's decisions'. A group is also set up to coordinate the period after corona. UPDATE: The original Taskforce consisted of only a few government bodies and is now being extended to encompass more ministries.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description:

The Coordination Group will also include the Director of Government Security Ahti Kurvinen, Director of Government Communications Paivi Anttikoski, Head of Unit Heikki Hovi and the Director of the National Institute for Health and Welfare Mika Salminen. The group is chaired by Mikko Koskinen. A Situation Center is also opened, which is operated under the Prime Minister's office, and is focused on monitoring corona and its effects. It is tasked with maintaining 'the situational picture and communicating it to the President of the Republic, the Government and other authorities'. An Operations Center is also established under the Prime Minister's Office 'to maintain an overall picture of the progress made in implementing the Government's decisions'. description: On 8 April, Finland's prime minister tasks a working group to prepare a plan for Finland's 'way out of the COVID-19 crisis' and an outline of measures to deal with its aftermath. The plan will include 'measures to rectify the health, social and economic damage caused by the coronavirus crisis and steps to be taken to lift the restrictions imposed to deal with the situation'. The group will work in cooperation with 'the business community, municipalities, civil society organisations and environmental organisations' as well as a number of a number of ministries and trade unions.

description: Finland's Ministry of the Interior announces that 'exceptions will be made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act in the case of critical personnel'. description: On April 3, the Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health and the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) distribute a letter to every household to 'provide every citizen with information' on the Coronavirus and on ways to avoid getting infected. According to the Director of Communications, Riikka Nurmi, 'there is a lot of talk about the coronavirus, the need for reliable information is on the increase. In the letter, we explain how you can protect yourself from getting coronavirus and how to act in case you get infected. In addition, the letter includes advice for people over 70 years of age because for them getting coronavirus may be a bigger risk'. The letter is expected to arrive at every household by April 9.

description: On 7 April 2020, Finnish Government announces that all persons arriving across internal borders with Sweden and Norway are obliged, during their stay in Finland, to remain under quarantine-like conditions for 14 days from their last entry to Finland. The requirement will not apply to essential emergency medical service and rescue service personnel or to freight transport personnel. Finns working in Sweden and Norway in the areas along the Finnish border must stay under quarantine-like conditions when they are in the territory of Finland. Employees coming to Finland from Sweden or Norway must stay in quarantine-like conditions, to the extent possible, both in Finland and during their stay at home.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

This policy does not apply to first responders, emergency service personnel, or members of the Border guard or customs. The policy will remain in place until 14 June. description: On June 12 2020, the Finnish government announces that from June 15, self-imposed quarantine is recommended for all arrivals in Finland who come from countries that are still subject to internal or external border control. Such countries are, for example, Sweden and Russia. Self-imposed quarantine is not required if a person arrives from Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, Denmark or Iceland. In self-imposed quarantine, you can move between your workplace and your place of residence. Other necessary movement is also possible.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 11 September, the Finnish government says that persons arriving from a country/region that is deemed to have a high incidence rate (25/100,000) should be in quarantine. Quarantined persons may end their quarantine upon receiving a negative test result from a second COVID test taken 72 hours after entry. Exceptions include special groups, such as representatives of culture, sports, and business life, who may be approved for entry for justifiable reasons. These reasons primarily include carrying out tasks necessary to secure the recovery, growth, or long-term conditions of a certain sector. Charter and group tours from both the EU and Schengen countries, as well as those from the EU's Green list are permitted, even if the country's incidence exceeds the 25/100,000 value if the tour lasts no more than 72 hours.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 17 March 2020, the Finnish government announces exceptions made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act, in both the private and public sector, to oblige trained professionals in healthcare and social welfare to perform work as necessary. If necessary, the employer is allowed to suspend of postpone the employee's leave and can also deviate from the obligation to obtain consent for the employee to work overtime. The employer can also extend the notice period to four months, if a shortage of labour, due to the coronavirus, is imminent.

description: On 31 March, the Finnish Government issued a decree restricting the operations of restaurants throughout the country. All restaurants must be closed starting from Saturday 4 April 2020. The restrictions will remain in force until the end of May. The restrictions apply to all restaurant operations except for preparing food for take away and for delivery by food couriers. The restrictions do not apply to canteens or restaurants that are essential for food supply such as canteens in schools, hospitals and similar establishments, or personnel restaurants that serve in-house personnel only. On May 19, the Finnish government decided to amend the previous policy, allowing for the reopening of restaurants under certain conditions, thereby ending the previous policy. UPDATE: The policy has been amended, therefore ending the previous policy.

description: On 26 May, the Finnish government announced a new set of regulations for rehabilitative work, overriding the previous policy that was set back in April. Beginning from 1 June, municipalities are to open their rehabilitative work facilities, including work activity centres, group-based social welfare services, group activities in social rehabilitation, or work and day activities for people with disabilities. Many municipalities closed their facilities when the government banned gatherings of more than 10 persons on 16 March, the national government encourages municipalities to reopen and use their discretion in deciding which alternative forms of rehabilitative work are offered.

update_level_var: [compliance] of policy relaxing ; timing of policy strengthening
description: On 8 October 2020, the Finnish government places mandatory restrictions on the opening hours of establishments that serve food and beverages. These establishments may open between the hours of 4:00 and 1:00, and alcohol may only be sold between the hours of 9:00 and 24:00. In areas of accelerated infection rates, food and beverage establishments must close by 23:00 and alcohol sales end by 22:00. The temporary decree will remain in force until 31 October 2020. UPDATE: On 1 November 2020, the policy was extended from 31 October 2020 until 28 February 2021 with added flexibility. Restrictions on opening hours do not apply to food and beverage service businesses on vessels and aircraft that operate between Finland and other countries or abroad or to food and beverage service businesses that operate at distributions stations for liquid fuels. Businesses subject to the restrictions may generally reopen one hour after closing. This means that a business that has stopped serving alcoholic beverages at 24.00 and must close at 1.00 may reopen as a night cafe starting at 2.00, for example.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

Restrictions on opening hours do not apply to food and beverage service businesses on vessels and aircraft that operate between Finland and other countries or abroad or to food and beverage service businesses that operate at distributions stations for liquid fuels. In addition, they will not be allowed to seat more than half of their normal number of customers inside their establishments." The restrictions will remain in force only for as long as necessary, but no longer than until 31 October 2020. UPDATE: On 1 November 2020, the policy was updated to limit businesses that primarily serve alcohol to remain open until 22:00, while all other food and beverage service businesses may stay open until 24:00. UPDATE: On 1 November 2020, the policy was updated to limit businesses that primarily serve alcohol to remain open until 22:00, while all other food and beverage service businesses may stay open until 24:00. Alcohol must stop being served by 22:00. The updated policy will remain in force until 15 December 2020.

description: On 8 October 2020, the Finnish government places mandatory restrictions on the opening hours of establishments that serve food and beverages. These establishments may open between the hours of 4:00 and 1:00, and alcohol may only be sold between the hours of 9:00 and 24:00. In areas of accelerated infection rates, food and beverage establishments must close by 23:00 and alcohol sales end by 22:00. The temporary decree will remain in force until 31 October 2020. UPDATE: On 6 November 2020, the Finnish government clarified the the temporary decree enacted on 1 November 2020. Businesses that reopen one hour after closing may not resume sales of alcoholic beverages, alcohol sales may start at 7:00 at the earliest. This amendment will remain in place until 15 December 2020.

description:
On 23 November 2020, Finnish authorities imposed stricter COVID-19 measures in the Helsinki metropolitan area and the whole of Uusimaa until 13 December 2020:
- Indoor public meetings of more than 20 people will be banned.
- Swimming halls, gyms, and other sports venues, cultural centers, museums, and libraries will remain open with social distancing rules applied and limits on capacities.
- Organizers of sports and cultural events, as well as private events, remain encouraged to recommend face mask usage.

description: On 23 November 2020, restrictions related to adult hobbies are announced in the Helsinki metropolitan area. The cities' own facilities will be closed for three weeks, until 13 December 2020, to sports that have been defined as team and contact sports. The suspension applies to activities for people over the age of 20, such as matches, competitions and series for adult hobby teams. For private operators, the authorities recommend the same suspension. The suspension does not apply to all sports in the group. Exercise is still allowed in the group if the safety distances can be maintained at all times.

description:
The Government has amended the decree restricting the activities of food and beverage service businesses due to the COVID-19 epidemic. Restrictions on food and beverage service businesses in Kainuu, North Karelia, Central Ostrobothnia and North Savo from Saturday 13 March 2021 onwards.The amount of customer seating in restaurants that primarily serve alcoholic beverages will be restricted to half the normal number of seats. Restaurants may serve alcoholic beverages until 22.00 and may be open between 5.00 and 23.00.

description: On 17 March 2020, the Finnish government announces exceptions made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act, in both the private and public sector, to oblige trained professionals in healthcare and social welfare to perform work as necessary. If necessary, the employer is allowed to suspend of postpone the employee's leave and can also deviate from the obligation to obtain consent for the employee to work overtime. The employer can also extend the notice period to four months, if a shortage of labour, due to the coronavirus, is imminent.

description: On 20 March 2020, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health "issued guidelines to municipalities on the operation of primary health and social services, including general guidance on rehabilitative work carried out under the responsibility of the municipalities. According to the guidance, the obligation to organise health and social services continues even in emergency conditions, and the municipalities must ensure their clients’ right to receive services in accordance with individual needs. Because of the risk of infection, group activities arranged in the same physical space are not possible now. During the coronavirus outbreak, rehabilitative work may include, for example, online coaching, remote tasks, individual guidance, and activities in workplaces where there is no risk of infection." These recommendations are valid until 31 July 2020.

description: Finland's Ministry of the Interior launches the #virutaaliveappu campaign, which encourages people to celebrate the annual vappu event, which marks the end of winter, at home. The campaign gives Finns alternative ways to spend vappu together through quarantine concerts and sima tasting on the sofa. Social media influencers are also taking part in spreading awareness. Vappu is traditionally celebrated together with friends and family outdoors.

description: On 14 May 2020, the Finnish government announces that public events with a maximum of 50 persons may be held in indoor and outdoor premises. Public meetings include demonstrations and other events that are open to all and that are organised in line with the right to freedom of assembly. Public events include entertainment events, competitions, performances or other similar events that are open to the public. The use of public sports facilities or visiting a shopping centre, for instance, do not constitute public meetings or public events
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"On June 11, the Finnish government updates its policy on outdoor events and say that the permitted number of attendees may exceed 500 persons if:
- event attendees can be placed in their own seating areas of viewing sections, each of which has a maximum capacity of 500 persons, with the ability to maintain safe distance and by providing hygiene instructions
- a clear buffer zone is arranged between each viewing section, have its own access routes, services (food/beverage/sanitary), event staff"
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 16 March 2020, the Finnish government bans visits to housing services for the elderly and other at-risk groups as well as care institutions, with the exception of asymptomatic family members of critically ill individuals and family members of those in hospice care, who will be permitted to visit on a case-by-case basis'. UPDATE: On April 9 2020, the Finnish government announces that policies enacted on 16 March to stop the spread of the coronavirus and protect vulnerable groups will be extended until 13 May 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18 April, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and health says that they do not recommend the use of medical face masks or fabric masks when moving in a public place for the general population. In its statement, the Ministry says that the respiratory protective equipment should be necessary for health care personnel openly and that the use of self-made fabric masks in public places 'may, at worst, lead to a false sense of security'.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 24 November 2020, Finland's THL announces that visits may be arranged on a case-by-case basis, 1-3 visitors at a time if agreed in advance, visitors must be asymptomatic, maintain good hygiene practices, wear masks, and maintain a safe distance of 1-2meters. Visitors must also have limited access to facilities and must heed the advice of the personnel. UPDATE: Changes to visitor restrictions in April 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 13 May 2020, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health issues new guidelines for facilities providing 24-hour care and treatment. These guidelines include that staff who come into close contact with patients must wear disposable surgical nose-masks or washable or disposable fabric masks that cover their nose and mouth in order to protect against any disease.
